posts.cooked: What examples do you have of the saying “There is nothing as permanent as a temporary solution” ? I’m training the team’s new programmers and want to talk to them about this, and I think real stories would help get the point across in a more interesting way (non-programming welcome too).

posts.name: chiefdelphiaddict
posts.cooked: im not really sure if this counts but as a temporary solution for the rest of the fw comp we had to duck tape our bumper after one of our qual matches because it got hit so hard and broke and still somehow managed to get picked for playoffs

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: a wise man once said that "DATA WINS CHAMPIONSHIPS!!"

posts.custom_user_title: a wise man once said that "DATA WINS CHAMPIONSHIPS!!"

posts.cooked:
“This auto sucks, fix later”

The auto: IMG_3999 1125×518 76.7 KB

IMG_3999 1125×518 76.7 KB

IMG_3999 1125×518 76.7 KB

(We did not, in fact, fix it later)

2022 States we broke our intake plates or something, and when we reassembled it, we were missing a spacer on one of the axles. We probably had enough time to partially disassemble the intake to put it back on, but testing was wanted, so we put a thicker ziptie on and ran with it.

That ziptie is still on the robot after States, Worlds, an Offseason, and 2 years of programming practice, it worked great!

At an FTC scrimmage, our claw for picking up pixels broke on the practice field, an hour before the first matches. So I quickly cut up a cardboard box and make a plow to push the game prices around. We ended up being a fully pusher robot that season. Also we ranked 2nd at that scrimmage with a cardboard pusher and zero auto.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Some people call me the Space Cowboy

posts.custom_user_title: Some people call me the Space Cowboy

posts.name: Justin| Alum|FRC 3035
posts.cooked: Reminds me of our team in 2019 when we won auto award even though our auto only consisted of leaving the habitat, and after the 1st qual match, we switched to manual camera drive for the rest of the comp lmao

posts.name: Stuart Rampy
posts.cooked: "OK, so Brown Coats or P-51 Mustangs. " “Just put in whatever we have till about a week before the competition to change it.”

I have two examples of this from recent(ish) years. The first is we quite literally had a rat trap on our robot in 2017 as a functioning mechanism, because it’s just what ended up working the best. The other would be last year’s solution to making sure we don’t drop the cones. After all our testing, we threw the last thing on there and it worked ( this was similar to what we used for reference ).

posts.name: Ben Thorsgard
posts.cooked: For the 2007 inner tube game, I bent a piece of 1”x1/4” aluminum over my knee a couple times to make a basic prototype tube grabber. It stayed on the final robot.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: The 2013 5-gallon pail hopper for the frisbees as well… pretty sure that was the only pail with those exact dimensions in the building (and i seem to remember it being green was a problem for a few people)

posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked:
Quite a few times we noticed a bolt coming out of something, and instead of disassembling and putting loctite in we would “temporarily” write it down to check before each match and then never put the loctite in.

Best practice imo is to check every bolt regardless of loctite, because they can come out occasionally.

Programming wise we usually have temporary diagnostic data that never gets turned off. We have gotten better in terms of limiting sysouts, because they take a while and can cause loop overruns. We usually have at least 30 shuffleboard outputs that we don’t turn off, but never look at.

We have a really old robot cart, from around 2009. The shelf where we usually put our driver station was wobbling, so we thought it might be time to replace the cart in the off-season. However, it was (iirc) in between our second district event (week 4) and DCMP , so one of our mentors put a 2x4 in to stabilize the shelf. The off-season has come around and we have too many other projects to replace our cart, so it’ll stay for at least one more year.

We have 2 ball screws as our climbers, and while testing in the pit during our 2nd regional event, we accidentally ran one all the way out, and flung ball bearings everwhere. We did our best to find all of them and put them back in, but we only managed around 1/2. We spent a while contenplating what to do, and decided to just leave it for now

Even after champs, the ball screw with half the bearings is still intact, and we plan on leaving it for the offseasons.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
Found this picture of you making the tube grabbers: image 1024×577 71.5 KB

image 1024×577 71.5 KB

image 1024×577 71.5 KB

For programming, it was our arm subsystem.  We temporarily tuned it with the motor encoders and dropped the speed down temporarily.  The encoder we thought we’d use on the shaft didn’t get installed and we didn’t require better controls for our strategy/abilities, so it stayed put.

Any 3d printed pulley or hub where you should have an aluminum COTS one.  They often seem to work pretty well, and for some application they’d been okay.  But we had a shooter with 3d printed hubs that we practiced with but eventually I had to insist that they would change them.  This year we had some temporary pulleys that were printed with less optimal fast settings, and we had spares that were done right, and it took until the pulley finally broke (at the 3rd competition) when they changed them.  (I forgot to add that the spares done right weren’t quite right with tooth count so 2357 was awesome and printed us another one at champs…thanks!)
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.cooked:
A couple more from the FTC world- my team couldn’t get our usual nice program structure to work even though it had worked last year, and we needed a simple teleop fast.  We used the example template, and it didn’t break, so we didn’t fix it.

Also, while rapid prototyping we very jankily slapped our linear slide onto our chassis using mismatched motor brackets and standard (not nyloc) nuts without loctite or anything.  Again, it didn’t break, so we didn’t fix it.  The loose nuts actually gave our slide a bit of useful compliance lol.
